learning_content.title: What is RAG (Retrieval-Augmented Generation)?
learning_content.content:
Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) is an AI architecture pattern that combines information retrieval with large language models (LLMs). Instead of relying only on what the model was trained on, RAG retrieves relevant documents from external data sources such as PDFs, databases, or knowledge bases at query time.

How RAG works:
1. User submits a query.
2. The query is converted into embeddings.
3. A vector database retrieves the most relevant documents.
4. Retrieved content is injected into the LLM prompt.
5. The model generates a grounded, factual response.

Benefits of RAG:
• Reduces hallucinations
• Enables up-to-date knowledge
• Allows private and domain-specific data usage
• Improves transparency and trust

Common use cases include chatbots, enterprise search, compliance assistants, and customer support systems.

learning_content.title: Prompt Engineering 101
learning_content.content:
Prompt engineering is the skill of writing effective instructions for AI models to get accurate, relevant, and high-quality outputs.

Core principles:
1. Be Clear – Avoid vague instructions.
2. Provide Context – Tell the AI who it is and what it should do.
3. Specify Format – Ask for bullet points, JSON, tables, etc.
4. Set Constraints – Limit length, tone, or scope.
5. Iterate – Improve prompts based on outputs.

Example:
Bad prompt: "Explain AI"
Good prompt: "Explain AI in simple terms for a beginner in under 100 words with examples."

Prompt engineering is useful for writing, coding, research, automation, and AI application development.

learning_content.title: Vector Databases Explained
learning_content.content:
Vector databases are specialized databases designed to store and search high-dimensional vector embeddings efficiently. They are a core component of modern AI systems, especially RAG pipelines.

Why vector databases are needed:
• Traditional databases cannot perform semantic similarity search
• AI models convert text, images, or audio into vectors
• Similar meanings produce nearby vectors in embedding space

Key operations:
1. Insert embeddings
2. Similarity search (cosine, dot-product, L2)
3. Metadata filtering

Popular vector databases include FAISS, Pinecone, Weaviate, Chroma, and Milvus.

Use cases:
• Semantic search
• Document retrieval
• Recommendation systems
• Chatbots with memory

learning_content.title: LLMs vs Traditional Machine Learning
learning_content.content:
Large Language Models (LLMs) differ significantly from traditional machine learning models in architecture, training, and usage.

Traditional ML:
• Task-specific models
• Requires labeled datasets
• Limited generalization

LLMs:
• Trained on massive text corpora
• Can perform multiple tasks with prompts
• Exhibit reasoning and language understanding

Key differences:
• LLMs use transformers
• LLMs support zero-shot and few-shot learning
• LLMs can be adapted using fine-tuning or RAG

Understanding these differences helps teams choose the right approach when building AI products.

learning_content.title: Building Your First AI Application
learning_content.content:
Building an AI application involves more than calling an API. A typical production-ready AI system includes multiple layers.

Core components:
1. Frontend (UI or API)
2. Backend orchestration
3. AI model or LLM
4. Data source (documents, DB, APIs)
5. Monitoring and logging

Best practices:
• Validate inputs and outputs
• Handle errors gracefully
• Add rate limits and caching
• Track latency and costs

This lesson prepares beginners to think like AI engineers, not just prompt users.
